question: Overall, people tell me that I’m likable and an easy person to get along with.
I don’t have trouble making or keeping friends.
Generally speaking, I want to be someone who makes other people happier and makes their lives easier.
I don’t really care about my friends’ problems—that’s not my responsibility.
When my friends or colleagues are sad, it doesn’t really affect me at all.
I’ve had people call me “cold,” “callous,” “uncaring,” or “mean.”
I’m generally more talented, smart, or special than other people.
I often find myself talking about my accomplishments—I even exaggerate them sometimes, to be honest.
Other people think my life is amazing, and they probably wish they were more like me.
When I’m angry or upset, I rarely hold my tongue. Instead, I might yell or hurl insults.
I’ve been called “rude” or “angry” by lots of people in the past.
I end up in conflicts more than other people do, probably because I don’t care if I offend people.
I don’t trust others easily, so I rarely open up to people.
In relationships, I feel like I have to check their phones and search for signs of cheating—even if they’ve always been trustworthy.
Generally speaking, I expect the worst in other people.
When people give me leverage in conversation (by sharing a secret, for instance), I take a mental note so I can use it later.
I tell people nice things that I don’t mean, just to get what I want.
I regularly try to influence people’s actions to help me achieve my end goal.
